abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Geofund
            Geothermal Project for Armenia were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, risk to global environment outcome was
            low or negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            include: the project design should allow flexibility
            regarding the types of field investigation works that can be
            financed. Thus, if types of field investigation works are
            strictly prescribed, then a project restructuring will be
            required, which may delay implementation of the project due
            to the time required for restructuring and subsequent
            probability of missing the favorable weather conditions.
            Procurement of technically sophisticated geo-technical
            studies should be initiated as early as possible. Given the
            technically complex nature of some geo-technical studies and
            non- availability of specialized firms in the local market
            as well as possible limited interest of internationally
            renowned firms, it is advisable to start procurement of such
            studies as early as possible. Otherwise, the consultant
            selection might result in very few or no bids for such
            consultancy services, which may require rebidding and delay
            project implementation.

14788087.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

repnme.cdata!:
Energy reforms in Armenia - On the way to
            energy security

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about energy
            reforms in Armenia. The development of renewable energy in
            Armenia was of triple importance. Firstly, it used local
            energy sources, secondly it used renewable energy sources
            and thirdly, it used clean sources of energy. Armenia
            Renewable Energy Project designed the scheme for small
            hydropower stations, and developed model business plans and
            guidelines for the renewable energy sector. Ninety Two
            hydropower stations were constructed under the project which
            would meet six percent of the internal demand for
            electricity. Besides providing electricity, small hydropower
            stations also provided jobs.

            energy security

repnme.cdata!:
Promoting safe and clean heating and
            increasing renewable energy generation in Armenia

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            promoting safe and clean heating, and increasing renewable
            energy generation in Armenia. Around 36 percent of residents
            of multi-apartment buildings relied on wood, household waste
            and other polluting fuels for heating, which were
            detrimental for health and the environment. The modern
            heater and gas connection costs were prohibitively high. Due
            to the lack of appropriate heating, many schools did not
            function during the winter months. World Bank supported
            Armenia by funding Urban Energy Project which focused on the
            use of safe, clean and affordable heating, and renewable
            energy generation. The World Bank energy program supported
            the government in improving the power transmission network
            infrastructure and reducing power supply gap.

13957857.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Second GeoFund Geothermal Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second GeoFund Geothermal Project
            development objective for Armenia is to assess the
            feasibility of exploratory drilling of the geothermal site
            with the estimated highest geothermal potential; this
            objective continues to be relevant. The extension is
            necessary to allow completion of the second phase
            investigation works for Karkar site, which has been
            identified as more promising based on first phase
            investigations. Second phase investigation works include
            three dimensional Magneto-Telluric (MT) sounding,
            interpretation of the results of the three dimensional MT
            sounding, supervision of the implementation of the
            three-dimensional MT sounding, and assessment of economic
            and financial viability of Karkar site. Second phase works
            were delayed because the project originally envisaged a
            three-dimensional seismic survey as part of second phase
            works, which was replaced by the three-dimensional MT
            sounding as explained in the restructuring paper of June 14,
            2010. Given this and the seasonal nature of investigation
            works, an extension until September 30, 2012 is necessary to
            complete second phase works.

display_title.display_title:
Armenia - Second GeoFund
            Geothermal Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
